ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to study for a language course, including memorization skills and specifically listening comprehension and oral development. I learned how to think critically and evaluate sources in Spanish as well, not purely memorization of grammar and vocabulary.

I learned about the various tenses in Spanish including but not limited to the preterite, the imperfect, and the past perfect. The numerous presentations involving various countries helped me learn more about the diversity of Spanish-speaking countries and helped me develop my oral speaking.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course forced a high level of engagement because of the pure number of assignments and evaluations. This meant that I was constantly working and retaining the language, however some of the assignments felt unnecessary (all of the projects, etc.). It was difficult to stay on top of all of the small assignments and weird due dates (some over the weekend, etc.). However, I liked the format of finishing worksheets at home and going over them in class in groups to share our answers and correct our work. It felt more efficient than using class time to complete the assignments. I wish we had talked more in a casual setting in the class. I think I would have felt more prepared for the oral exam if we had done this.
I think we could have spent more time on grammar during class

This course not only teaches grammar and vocabulary, but also immerses students in topics of cultural significance through its projects. I liked how in addition to teaching the rules of the language, it also gave students a deeper look of the worldwide impact of the language.
Strengths are the structure and opportunities for tutoring
I believe that in person lectures will be better than online learning, but this lecture format still did well despite this weakness.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course used breakout rooms well because it is really important to collaborate with peers and talk, both about the assignments and more casual Spanish conversation. I actually felt like I got to know people in my class, which I can't say for any of my other Zoom classes. Additionally, the exams,  compositions, and presentations were smoothly run, despite the added difficulties of Zoom. I can't think of anything specific to be improved. Language classes are better in person, but there isn't anything that the class could do to improve that - I think they made the best of the situation.
Im not really sure what was changed for Covid, but it might have been helpful to do more partner grabaciones

I think this course has adapted well to being remote. Even though we only met three times a week, there were enough activities to keep students engaged in learning the language including exercises and movie assignments. There were also plenty of opportunities to work with other students and have exchanges in Spanish. I think conversation was very helpful in practicing what we have learned.
the good course practices were breakout rooms!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student if they specifically wanted to learn Spanish. However, if they were just looking for a language to learn, I would not because the number of tiny assignments and constant work of this class is overwhelming. Additionally, the grading is relatively harsh and the expectations are daunting.

Yes, I would! This course was wonderful and small class sizes provide opportunity to get feedback for your work. I have learned a lot about the language and have begun understanding much more when consuming media in Spanish.
yes, great way to learn spanish
If this person is interested in Spanish, I would recommend this course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
